title: Introduction to degen
text: Two statistical models observationally equivalent assign probability every possible dataset. occurs, amount data can distinguish . matters : Different model formulations may encode different mechanistic stories formulations observationally equivalent, data tell us story correct Conclusions drawn one formulation versus another assumptions, results

title: Introduction to degen
text: parameter identifiable value can uniquely determined likelihood function. Non-identifiable parameters exhibit flat likelihood surfaces direction, meaning data provide information distinguishing values along direction.

title: Introduction to degen
text: degen provides tools : Detect observational equivalence model specifications Diagnose identifiability problems within single model Characterize equivalence classes among multiple competing models

title: Introduction to degen
text: Models defined log-likelihood functions using model_spec():
code: # Exponential model exp_spec <- model_spec(   loglik_fn = function(y, lambda) sum(dexp(y, rate = lambda, log = TRUE)),   par_names = "lambda",   par_bounds = list(lambda = c(1e-6, Inf)),   name = "Exponential" )  # Gamma model with shape = 1 (equivalent to exponential) gamma1_spec <- model_spec(   loglik_fn = function(y, rate) {     sum(dgamma(y, shape = 1, rate = rate, log = TRUE))   },   par_names = "rate",   par_bounds = list(rate = c(1e-6, Inf)),   name = "Gamma(1)" )  # Gamma model with shape = 2 (not equivalent) gamma2_spec <- model_spec(   loglik_fn = function(y, rate) {     sum(dgamma(y, shape = 2, rate = rate, log = TRUE))   },   par_names = "rate",   par_bounds = list(rate = c(1e-6, Inf)),   name = "Gamma(2)" )

title: Introduction to degen
text: Create equivalence pair compare likelihood surfaces:
code: pair <- equivalence_pair(exp_spec, gamma1_spec)  set.seed(123) y <- rexp(100, rate = 2)  result <- compare_surfaces(pair, y, n_points = 30, tol = 1e-4) print(result) #> <surface_comparison> #> Conclusion: Models appear EQUIVALENT #> Points tested: 60 #> Max discrepancy: 4.83e-06 #> Tolerance: 1.00e-04 #> Method: grid

title: Introduction to degen
text: single model, check whether parameters identifiable:
code: # A model where only a + b is identified nonid_spec <- model_spec(   loglik_fn = function(y, a, b) {     sum(dnorm(y, mean = a + b, sd = 1, log = TRUE))   },   par_names = c("a", "b"),   name = "Non-identifiable" )  set.seed(123) y_norm <- rnorm(100, mean = 5, sd = 1)  id_result <- identifiability_check(nonid_spec, y_norm, par = c(a = 2, b = 3)) print(id_result) #> <identifiability_result> #> Overall: Model has NON-IDENTIFIABLE parameters #>  #> Parameter status: #>   a: NON-IDENTIFIABLE #>   b: NON-IDENTIFIABLE #>  #> Non-identified directions: #>   -0.71*a + 0.71*b #>  #> Identified functions: #>   0.71*a + 0.71*b #>  #> Condition number: 3.1e+12 #> Rank: 1 / 2

title: Introduction to degen
text: multiple candidate models, group equivalence:
code: models <- list(   exp = exp_spec,   gamma1 = gamma1_spec,   gamma2 = gamma2_spec )  set.seed(123) y <- rexp(50, rate = 2)  classes <- equivalence_classes(models, y, n_points = 15, tol = 1e-4) print(classes) #> <equiv_classes> #> 3 models -> 2 equivalence classes #>  #> Class 1: exp, gamma1 (equivalent) #> Class 2: gamma2

title: Introduction to degen
text: model_spec contains: loglik_fn: function signature function(y, ...) returning log-likelihood par_names: Names parameters par_bounds: Optional bounds parameter

title: Introduction to degen
text: compare_surfaces() samples parameter space checks whether parameter configuration model can matched configuration model B (vice versa).

title: Introduction to degen
text: identifiability_check() uses: Fisher information: curvature log-likelihood surface Eigenvalue analysis: Near-zero eigenvalues indicate non-identifiable directions Profile likelihood: Optional deeper analysis individual parameters

title: Introduction to degen
text: package designed researchers : Work models structural assumptions matter Need assess whether competing mechanistic hypotheses empirically distinguishable Want diagnose certain parameters poorly estimated

title: Introduction to degen
text: provides numerical evidence, mathematical proof Conclusions depend tolerance number test points High-dimensional parameter spaces computationally challenging

what: Detect Observational Equivalence and Non-Identifiability in Models
title: Detect Observational Equivalence and Non-Identifiability in Models
text: R package detecting observational equivalence, degeneracy, non-identifiability parametric models.

title: Detect Observational Equivalence and Non-Identifiability in Models
text: Statistical models encode assumptions data-generating processes. Different model formulations (different parameterizations, latent structures, functional forms) can sometimes produce identical distributions observable data. occurs, amount data can distinguish . models observationally equivalent. package provides tools : Detect whether two model specifications induce likelihood surface Diagnose identifiability problems within single model Characterize equivalence classes among competing formulations

title: Detect Observational Equivalence and Non-Identifiability in Models
text: Observational equivalence: Two models observationally equivalent assign probability every possible dataset. Formally, data yy sample space, exist parameter values θA\theta_A θB\theta_B ℒA(y;θA)=ℒB(y;θB)\mathcal{L}_A(y; \theta_A) = \mathcal{L}_B(y; \theta_B). Degeneracy: model exhibits degeneracy multiple parameter configurations yield identical likelihoods. failure injectivity mapping parameters distributions. Non-identifiability: parameter non-identifiable likelihood function constant along direction parameter space. data provide information distinguishing values along direction. concepts related distinct. Degeneracy concerns structure single model’s parameter space. Equivalence concerns relationships different models. matter inference.

title: Detect Observational Equivalence and Non-Identifiability in Models
code: # From GitHub (development version) # install.packages("pak") pak::pak("gcol33/degen")

title: Detect Observational Equivalence and Non-Identifiability in Models
text: Define two model specifications providing log-likelihood functions: identifiability diagnostics single model:
code: library(degen)  # Model A: simple exponential spec_a <- model_spec(   loglik_fn = function(y, lambda) sum(dexp(y, rate = lambda, log = TRUE)),   par_names = "lambda",   par_bounds = list(lambda = c(1e-6, Inf)) )  # Model B: Gamma with shape fixed at 1 (equivalent to exponential) spec_b <- model_spec(   loglik_fn = function(y, rate) sum(dgamma(y, shape = 1, rate = rate, log = TRUE)),   par_names = "rate",   par_bounds = list(rate = c(1e-6, Inf)) )  # Compare likelihood surfaces pair <- equivalence_pair(spec_a, spec_b) result <- compare_surfaces(pair, y = rexp(100, rate = 2)) # Check Fisher information for near-singularity info <- fisher_information(spec_a, y = rexp(100), par = c(lambda = 2)) identifiability_check(info)

what: What This Package Does Not Do
title: Detect Observational Equivalence and Non-Identifiability in Models
text: Model fitting: degen estimate parameters. examines properties likelihood functions. Model selection: package rank models fit, predictive accuracy, information criteria. Causal inference: Observational equivalence statement likelihoods, causal structure. Two models may observationally equivalent yet encode different causal claims. Automated model extraction: Users must supply likelihood functions explicitly. package extract likelihoods fitted model objects.

title: Detect Observational Equivalence and Non-Identifiability in Models
text: package designed researchers : Work models structural assumptions matter (e.g., population dynamics, species distribution models, mixture models) Need assess whether competing mechanistic hypotheses empirically distinguishable Want diagnose certain parameters poorly estimated Familiarity likelihood-based inference assumed. package provides diagnostics, tutorials identifiability theory.

title: Detect Observational Equivalence and Non-Identifiability in Models
text: problem observational equivalence long history econometrics, psychometrics, structural equation modeling. package replicate replace specialized tools domains. provides general framework likelihood-based equivalence detection applicable across disciplines.

title: Detect Observational Equivalence and Non-Identifiability in Models

what: Compare likelihood surfaces between two models — compare_surfaces
title: Compare likelihood surfaces between two models — compare_surfaces
text: Test whether two model specifications observationally equivalent comparing likelihood surfaces. parameter configuration model , algorithm searches configuration model B produces likelihood.

title: Compare likelihood surfaces between two models — compare_surfaces
code: compare_surfaces(   pair,   y,   n_points = 100,   method = c("grid", "optimization"),   tol = 1e-06,   verbose = FALSE )

title: Compare likelihood surfaces between two models — compare_surfaces
text: pair equivalence_pair object y Numeric vector observed data n_points Number parameter points sample (default 100) method Comparison method: "grid" samples parameter space, "optimization" searches counterexamples tol Tolerance likelihood equality (default 1e-6) verbose Logical; print progress information

title: Compare likelihood surfaces between two models — compare_surfaces
text: S3 object class surface_comparison containing: equivalent Logical; overall equivalence conclusion max_discrepancy Maximum likelihood discrepancy found n_tested Number parameter points tested evidence Data frame tested points discrepancies tol Tolerance used method Method used

title: Compare likelihood surfaces between two models — compare_surfaces
text: comparison performed directions (B B ) ensure equivalence relation symmetric. Note provides numerical evidence, mathematical proof. conclusion equivalence means counterexample found within tested region parameter space.

title: Compare likelihood surfaces between two models — compare_surfaces
code: # Compare exponential and gamma(shape=1) - these are equivalent exp_spec <- model_spec(   loglik_fn = function(y, lambda) sum(dexp(y, rate = lambda, log = TRUE)),   par_names = "lambda",   par_bounds = list(lambda = c(1e-6, Inf)),   name = "Exponential" )  gamma_spec <- model_spec(   loglik_fn = function(y, rate) {     sum(dgamma(y, shape = 1, rate = rate, log = TRUE))   },   par_names = "rate",   par_bounds = list(rate = c(1e-6, Inf)),   name = "Gamma(1)" )  pair <- equivalence_pair(exp_spec, gamma_spec) set.seed(123) y <- rexp(100, rate = 2) result <- compare_surfaces(pair, y, n_points = 20) print(result) #> <surface_comparison> #> Conclusion: Models are NOT EQUIVALENT #> Points tested: 40 #> Max discrepancy: 2.90e-06 #> Tolerance: 1.00e-06 #> Method: grid

what: degen: Detect Observational Equivalence and Non-Identifiability in Models — degen-package
title: degen: Detect Observational Equivalence and Non-Identifiability in Models — degen-package
text: Tools detecting whether statistical model specifications observationally equivalent, diagnosing identifiability problems, characterizing equivalence classes among competing formulations.

title: degen: Detect Observational Equivalence and Non-Identifiability in Models — degen-package
text: Maintainer: Gilles Colling gilles.colling@uclouvain.

what: Find equivalence classes among multiple models — equivalence_classes
title: Find equivalence classes among multiple models — equivalence_classes
text: Given list model specifications, determine models observationally equivalent group equivalence classes.

title: Find equivalence classes among multiple models — equivalence_classes
code: equivalence_classes(specs, y, n_points = 50, tol = 1e-06, verbose = FALSE)

title: Find equivalence classes among multiple models — equivalence_classes
text: specs named list model_spec objects y Numeric vector observed data n_points Number parameter points sample comparison tol Tolerance equivalence (default 1e-6) verbose Logical; print progress

title: Find equivalence classes among multiple models — equivalence_classes
text: S3 object class equiv_classes containing: classes List equivalence classes (vectors model names) n_classes Number distinct classes membership Named vector mapping model names class indices pairwise Matrix pairwise equivalence results discrepancies Matrix pairwise discrepancies

title: Find equivalence classes among multiple models — equivalence_classes
text: algorithm performs pairwise comparisons models uses union-find group equivalent models. Two models considered equivalent maximum likelihood discrepancy tolerance.

title: Find equivalence classes among multiple models — equivalence_classes
code: # Define several models exp_spec <- model_spec(   loglik_fn = function(y, lambda) sum(dexp(y, rate = lambda, log = TRUE)),   par_names = "lambda",   par_bounds = list(lambda = c(1e-6, 100)),   name = "Exponential" )  gamma1_spec <- model_spec(   loglik_fn = function(y, rate) sum(dgamma(y, shape = 1, rate = rate, log = TRUE)),   par_names = "rate",   par_bounds = list(rate = c(1e-6, 100)),   name = "Gamma(1)" )  gamma2_spec <- model_spec(   loglik_fn = function(y, rate) sum(dgamma(y, shape = 2, rate = rate, log = TRUE)),   par_names = "rate",   par_bounds = list(rate = c(1e-6, 100)),   name = "Gamma(2)" )  models <- list(exp = exp_spec, gamma1 = gamma1_spec, gamma2 = gamma2_spec)  set.seed(123) y <- rexp(50, rate = 2) classes <- equivalence_classes(models, y, n_points = 10) print(classes) #> <equiv_classes> #> 3 models -> 3 equivalence classes #>  #> Class 1: exp #> Class 2: gamma1 #> Class 3: gamma2

what: Create an equivalence pair for model comparison — equivalence_pair
title: Create an equivalence pair for model comparison — equivalence_pair
text: Pairs two model specifications equivalence comparison. pair represents question: "two models observationally equivalent?"

title: Create an equivalence pair for model comparison — equivalence_pair
code: equivalence_pair(spec_a, spec_b, name = NULL)

title: Create an equivalence pair for model comparison — equivalence_pair
text: spec_a model_spec object (first model) spec_b model_spec object (second model) name Optional character string naming comparison. NULL, name generated model names.

title: Create an equivalence pair for model comparison — equivalence_pair
text: S3 object class equivalence_pair components: spec_a First model specification spec_b Second model specification name Comparison name n_par_a Number parameters model n_par_b Number parameters model B

title: Create an equivalence pair for model comparison — equivalence_pair
code: # Compare exponential and gamma(shape=1) models exp_spec <- model_spec(   loglik_fn = function(y, lambda) sum(dexp(y, rate = lambda, log = TRUE)),   par_names = "lambda",   par_bounds = list(lambda = c(1e-6, Inf)),   name = "Exponential" )  gamma_spec <- model_spec(   loglik_fn = function(y, rate) {     sum(dgamma(y, shape = 1, rate = rate, log = TRUE))   },   par_names = "rate",   par_bounds = list(rate = c(1e-6, Inf)),   name = "Gamma(1)" )  pair <- equivalence_pair(exp_spec, gamma_spec) print(pair) #> <equivalence_pair> Exponential vs Gamma(1)  #> Model A: Exponential (1 parameter) #> Model B: Gamma(1) (1 parameter)

title: Compute Fisher information matrix — fisher_information
text: Compute observed Fisher information matrix (negative Hessian log-likelihood) model specification given parameter values.

title: Compute Fisher information matrix — fisher_information
code: fisher_information(   spec,   y,   par,   type = c("observed", "expected"),   method = c("hessian") )

title: Compute Fisher information matrix — fisher_information
text: spec model_spec object y Numeric vector observed data par Named numeric vector parameter values evaluate type Type information: "observed" (default) uses negative Hessian data; "expected" use theoretical expectation (yet implemented) method Computation method: "hessian" (default) uses numerical differentiation

title: Compute Fisher information matrix — fisher_information
text: S3 object class fisher_info containing: matrix Fisher information matrix eigenvalues Eigenvalues (sorted decreasing) eigenvectors Corresponding eigenvectors condition Condition number rank Numerical rank par Parameter values used par_names Parameter names

title: Compute Fisher information matrix — fisher_information
text: Fisher information matrix characterizes curvature log-likelihood surface. Key properties: Positive definite: parameters locally identifiable Singular (rank deficient): parameters identifiable Near-singular (high condition number): parameters weakly identified

title: Compute Fisher information matrix — fisher_information
code: spec <- model_spec(   loglik_fn = function(y, mu, sigma) {     sum(dnorm(y, mean = mu, sd = sigma, log = TRUE))   },   par_names = c("mu", "sigma"),   par_bounds = list(sigma = c(1e-6, Inf)) )  set.seed(123) y <- rnorm(100, mean = 5, sd = 2) info <- fisher_information(spec, y, par = c(mu = 5, sigma = 2)) print(info) #> <fisher_info> at par = (mu=5, sigma=2) #> Condition number: 1.7 #> Rank: 2 / 2 (full) #> Eigenvalues: 38.9, 23.5

title: Check model identifiability — identifiability_check
text: Perform comprehensive identifiability analysis model specification. Combines Fisher information analysis profile likelihood diagnostics.

title: Check model identifiability — identifiability_check
code: identifiability_check(   spec,   y,   par = NULL,   level = c("local", "profile"),   threshold = 0.01,   verbose = FALSE )

title: Check model identifiability — identifiability_check
text: spec model_spec object y Numeric vector observed data par Named numeric vector parameter values. NULL, attempts find MLE first. level Analysis level: "local" uses Fisher information , "profile" adds profile likelihood analysis threshold Eigenvalue threshold non-identifiability (default 0.01) verbose Logical; print progress information

title: Check model identifiability — identifiability_check
text: S3 object class identifiability_result containing: status Named character vector identifiability status per parameter fisher_info Fisher information analysis identified_functions Character vector identified parameter combinations non_identified Character vector non-identified directions condition Condition number rank Numerical rank recommendations Suggested actions

title: Check model identifiability — identifiability_check
code: # Well-identified model norm_spec <- model_spec(   loglik_fn = function(y, mu, sigma) {     sum(dnorm(y, mean = mu, sd = sigma, log = TRUE))   },   par_names = c("mu", "sigma"),   par_bounds = list(sigma = c(1e-6, Inf)) )  set.seed(123) y <- rnorm(100, mean = 5, sd = 2) result <- identifiability_check(norm_spec, y, par = c(mu = 5, sigma = 2)) print(result) #> <identifiability_result> #> Overall: Model appears WELL-IDENTIFIED #>  #> Parameter status: #>   mu: identified #>   sigma: identified #>  #> Condition number: 1.7 #> Rank: 2 / 2  # Non-identifiable model nonid_spec <- model_spec(   loglik_fn = function(y, a, b) {     sum(dnorm(y, mean = a + b, sd = 1, log = TRUE))   },   par_names = c("a", "b") )  result2 <- identifiability_check(nonid_spec, y, par = c(a = 2, b = 3)) print(result2) #> <identifiability_result> #> Overall: Model has NON-IDENTIFIABLE parameters #>  #> Parameter status: #>   a: NON-IDENTIFIABLE #>   b: NON-IDENTIFIABLE #>  #> Non-identified directions: #>   0.71*a -0.71*b #>  #> Identified functions: #>   -0.71*a -0.71*b #>  #> Condition number: 3e+12 #> Rank: 1 / 2

code: spec <- model_spec(   loglik_fn = function(y, lambda) sum(dexp(y, rate = lambda, log = TRUE)),   par_names = "lambda",   par_bounds = list(lambda = c(1e-6, Inf)) ) y <- rexp(100, rate = 2) loglik(spec, y, par = c(lambda = 2)) #> [1] -34.74517

title: Create a model specification — model_spec
text: Define parametric model log-likelihood function. foundational object equivalence identifiability analysis.

title: Create a model specification — model_spec
code: model_spec(   loglik_fn,   par_names,   par_bounds = NULL,   name = NULL,   validate = TRUE )

title: Create a model specification — model_spec
text: loglik_fn function signature function(y, ...) y data ... named parameters. Must return scalar log-likelihood. par_names Character vector parameter names. Must match argument names loglik_fn (excluding y). par_bounds Optional named list parameter bounds. element length-2 numeric vector c(lower, upper). Parameters specified default c(-Inf, Inf). name Optional character string naming model. NULL, name generated parameter names. validate Logical; TRUE (default), validate inputs construction. Set FALSE performance tight loops.

title: Create a model specification — model_spec
text: S3 object class model_spec components: loglik_fn log-likelihood function par_names Character vector parameter names par_bounds Named list bounds parameter n_par Number parameters name Model name

title: Create a model specification — model_spec
code: # Exponential model exp_spec <- model_spec(   loglik_fn = function(y, lambda) sum(dexp(y, rate = lambda, log = TRUE)),   par_names = "lambda",   par_bounds = list(lambda = c(1e-6, Inf)),   name = "Exponential" )  # Normal model with two parameters norm_spec <- model_spec(   loglik_fn = function(y, mu, sigma) {     sum(dnorm(y, mean = mu, sd = sigma, log = TRUE))   },   par_names = c("mu", "sigma"),   par_bounds = list(sigma = c(1e-6, Inf)) )

text: Matrix column null direction, NULL none

title: Find directions of non-identifiability — null_directions
code: # Model where only a+b is identified, not a and b individually spec <- model_spec(   loglik_fn = function(y, a, b) {     sum(dnorm(y, mean = a + b, sd = 1, log = TRUE))   },   par_names = c("a", "b") )  set.seed(123) y <- rnorm(100, mean = 5, sd = 1) info <- fisher_information(spec, y, par = c(a = 2, b = 3)) null_directions(info) #>       null_1 #> a -0.7071068 #> b  0.7071068

code: exp_spec <- model_spec(   loglik_fn = function(y, lambda) sum(dexp(y, rate = lambda, log = TRUE)),   par_names = "lambda" ) norm_spec <- model_spec(   loglik_fn = function(y, mu, sigma) sum(dnorm(y, mu, sigma, log = TRUE)),   par_names = c("mu", "sigma") ) pair <- equivalence_pair(exp_spec, norm_spec) par_dims(pair)  # c(a = 1, b = 2) #> a b  #> 1 2

title: degen 0.9.0
text: Added comprehensive integration tests Added shared test fixtures helper-fixtures.R Verified complete workflows end--end Tested edge cases consistency properties

title: degen 0.8.0
text: Added introduction vignette examples Organized pkgdown reference topic Added vignette dependencies (knitr, rmarkdown)

title: degen 0.7.0
text: Added equivalence_classes() grouping multiple models equivalence Added n_classes(), class_members(), are_equivalent() utilities Union-find algorithm efficient class detection Added is_equiv_classes() type predicate

title: degen 0.6.0
text: Added identifiability_check() comprehensive identifiability diagnostics Added profile_likelihood() profile likelihood analysis Automatic parameter classification (identified/weakly/non-identifiable) Recommendations addressing identifiability issues Added is_identifiability_result() type predicate

title: degen 0.5.0
text: Added fisher_information() computing observed Fisher information Added info_eigenvalues(), info_condition(), info_rank() accessors Added null_directions() find non-identifiable parameter combinations Added is_fisher_info() type predicate

title: degen 0.4.0
text: Added compare_surfaces() detecting observational equivalence Grid-based comparison multi-start optimization Latin hypercube sampling parameter space exploration Added is_surface_comparison() type predicate

title: degen 0.3.0
text: Added equivalence_pair() pairing models comparison Added spec_a(), spec_b() accessors Added par_dims(), same_par_count() utilities Added is_equivalence_pair() type predicate

title: degen 0.2.0
text: Added model_spec() defining models via log-likelihood functions Added generics: par_names(), par_bounds(), n_par(), loglik() Added is_model_spec() type predicate S3 methods: print, summary, format model_spec

title: degen 0.1.0
text: Initial package structure Added internal validation utilities (check_numeric(), check_function(), check_bounds()) Set GitHub Actions R CMD check, test coverage, pkgdown
